_prev_prog_2.Description:
8.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2, SUBPART C

The Geocycle prevention program covers both Processes  

The Geocycle Hazardous Waste Derived Fuels (HWDF) systems and feed to the Holcim cement kiln, related utility and safety systems are subject to the requirements of EPA's Prevention Program Level 2.  

Geocycle has developed and implemented seven elements required by Prevention Program Level 2:

1.    Safety Information            68.48

2.    Hazard Review                    68.50

3.    Operating Procedures            68.52

4.    Training                68.54

5.    Compliance Audits            68.58

6.    Incident Investigation            68.60

7.    Maintenance                68.56



7.1.    SAFETY INFORMATION    68.48

Geocycle compiled the safety information required under the RMP regulations.  The safety information assists in the understanding of the safety-related aspects of the equipment and processes, and the limitations placed on the operations and the adopted codes and standards.  First, Geocycle receives hazardous waste and uses a detailed chemical analysis and physical property analysis to define each waste stream.  There are no MSDS or SDSs for hazardous waste.   Next, the bulk containers used for delivering the waste fuel containing the RMP compounds are DOT-specification containers and are required to be tested periodically for tightness and adequacy for carrying hazardous materials.  Documentation of the safety and design information on the typical process equipment, along with the corresponding design codes, is maintained in the plant's current RCRA Permit Application in Section4 - Storage and Process Information (4.3 Hazardous Waste Management), Operations SOPs for Operating Limits and Temporary Operations, Engineering and Maintenance Records.  The 2011/2012 EPD audit report and equipment evaluation confirmed all of the equipment installations were within code.  The information contained on the Safety Information Sheet is reviewed and updated on a periodic basis for completeness and accuracy.  The maximum intended inventory for each RMP Toxic Chemical is listed in the List of Chemicals in Table #1 and #2..  



7.2.    HAZARD REVIEW    68.50

The facility completed several hazard reviews (HR) of its RMP regulated process (HWDF) facility operations. A Hazard Review was conducted on October 31, 2014 of the improvements to the Vapor Recovery System and a Hazard Review was conducted on March 24, 2015 of the expansion of the Sprinkler System in the Receiving areas. A Hazard Review was conducted on December 17, 18, and 19, 2012 of the RMP regulated process.  In 2011 a complete explosibility and electrical systems review was completed.  Then in September 2009, a Hazard Review and audit of the blend tanks and derived fuel system was conducted. Again in January  2008 for the Direct Burn Process and September 2006,and Management of Change Review, February 6, 2007 for the Blend Tank Process (update to the initial HR performed in June 2001 and December 1999). the HR used a structured "what-if" for the most of the evaluations. The more complete Hazards and Operability (HazOp) technique  was used for the 2011 review.  Each HR used a multidisciplinary team to conduct the evaluation.



The HR identified:

7.2.1.    Hazards associated with the process and regulated chemicals

7.2.2.    Potential for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause a release

7.2.3.    Safeguards that control the hazards or prevent the malfunction or error

7.2.4.    Steps to detect or monitor releases

The HR results have been documented and are retained on file at the facility.  Implementation of the HR recommendations is ongoing and essentially a continuing process.  The Hazard Review shall be updated minimally every 5 years or with any process or equipment change that occurs that impacts the covered processes. 



7.3.    OPERATING PROCEDURES    68.52

Geocycle has written operating procedures (OPs) that describe in detail what tasks a process operator must perform.  The OPs set safe process operating parameters that must be maintained.  It lists the set safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.  These procedures are the guide for employees on how to work safely, providing a readily accessible source of comprehensive information that can prevent or mitigate the effects of an accident.  Finally it provides workers and management with a standard against which to assess performance.



Geocycle must have written operating procedures for each of the following:

7.3.1.    Initial start-up

7.3.2.    Normal operations

7.3.3.    Temporary operations

7.3.4.    Emergency shutdown

7.3.5.    Emergency operations

7.3.6.    Normal shutdown

7.3.7.    Start up following a normal or emergency shutdown or a major change

7.3.8.    Consequence of deviation and steps required to avoid or correct deviations and

7.3.9.    Equipment inspection



The operating procedures shall be updated any time there is a change in the process in a way that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Examples of changes that may require an update to the operating procedures include:   the installation of new operating equipment, a change in the safety information for the regulated chemical or process equipment, as well as the identification of additional hazards during the updates to the facility hazard review.



7.4.    TRAINING    68.54

Under the RMP regulation in 40 CFR Part 68.54, all new workers and experienced workers are trained in the Operating Procedures prior to starting working on an RMP covered process.  Also, training is given any time the procedures are revised as everyone must be trained in using the new procedures.  Training for the RMP program is given at least once every three years  Finally, training will be given more often if necessary, employees will be consulted by Geocycle to establish a refresher training regimen.  Refresher training is provided on the operating procedures even if they have not changed.  The training must cover all parts of the operating procedures, including information on the consequences of deviations and steps needed to address deviations. 



Under the provisions of 40 CFR ? 68.54(c), the facility "may use training conducted under Federal or state regulations or under industry specific standards or codes or training conducted by covered process equipment vendors to demonstrate compliance with this section to the extent that the training meets the requirements of this section".  Under the prevailing federal RCRA regulations, all HWDF facility and cement plant employees associated with hazardous waste operations are trained within 6 months of hire.  The training includes the following:

24 Hours initial RCRA/MSHA hazardous waste operations and emergency training  

8 hours RCRA/MSHA annual refresher training

Classroom and on-the-job training is conducted, along with written examinations as required.  All training logs and records are maintained on site.



7.5.    MAINTENANCE    68.56

Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment are critical to safe operations.  Geocycle has developed and implemented procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of process equipment.. We also train applicable workers and contractors in the maintenance procedures, under 40 CFR 68.52, 54 and 56. 

As required under 40 CFR 264/265, the facility has implemented Procedures to Prevent Hazards  as an integral part of its hazardous waste management operations.  These written procedures meet or exceed the requirements for preventive maintenance, inspection and testing under the RMP regulations and are incorporated by reference.  They provide a detailed list of the equipment to be tested and the inspection frequency.  The schedules already in practice are based on: 

7.5.1.    Regulatory Compliance Requirements

7.5.2.    Manufacturer's Recommendations

7.5.3.    Industry Standards or Codes

7.5.4.    Good Engineering Practices

All employees associated with preventive maintenance, inspection and testing are trained in these procedures.



7.6.    COMPLIANCE AUDITS     68.58

Geocycle will review and audit the RMP Plan every three years, at a minimum, to ensure that the plan is implemented and documented adequately.  The audit program is designed to evaluate and measure the effectiveness of the Risk Management Program and ensure that the prevention program elements are up-to-date and appropriate for current operations.



The compliance audit will be conducted every by an individual (or team); knowledgeable of both the regulated processes as well as the RMP regulations [40 CFR Part 68].  The compliance audit will include a review of all elements of the RMP plan level 2 program, including:

7.6.1.    Safety Information

7.6.2.    Hazard Review

7.6.3.    Change in Regulated Process or Regulated Chemicals

7.6.4.    Records



Upon completion of the compliance audit, all findings shall be summarized in a written report.  Geocycle will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each audit finding and further document all corrective actions taken to address any deficiencies.  Copies of the two most recent compliance audits and documentation of all corrective actions will be maintained at the facility.  A copy of the blank audit form used by South Carolina DHEC is included in Appendix 7.



7.7.    Incident Investigation    68.60

Geocycle will perform an investigation of each incident which has resulted in, or could have resulted in a release or catastrophic release of a regulated chemical.  A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  An RMP reportable release is one that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage



The following steps will be taken in performing an incident investigation:

7.7.1.    Initiate an investigation as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident.

7.7.2.    Summarize the investigation in a report.  Incorporate all factors contributing to the incident including:  date of incident; date investigation began, a description of the incident; the factors that contributed to the incident; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation.

7.7.3.    Address the investigation findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions shall be documented.

7.7.4.    The findings shall be reviewed with all affected personnel to prevent future occurrence of similar incidents

7.7.5.    Each investigation report is maintained for a minimum of five years.

_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: The OSHA standard is used as a guide
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen is used to pressurize and purge the transfer line

_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Level 2 Prevention Program for the Direct Burn Operations is identical to the prevention program for the Derived Fuel Operations.



All of the chemicals in the Derived Fuel Operations can be processed in the Direct Burn Operation.  There are nine other chemicals that can only be processed in the Direct Burn process.  Note the operators and maintenance staff that work in the Derived Fuel Operations also work in the Direct Burn Operations.

_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: 20 gallons of a NON-RMP Mixture was released when transfering to an RMP covered Process.
_accidents.ED_Other: Spill was to a containment area and did not affect soil.
_accidents.CI_OtherType: 11/5/2015  Reviewed with all affected employees and required use of full face respirator during tanker connection operatoins

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: SC DHEC Bureau of Air Quality

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY, 68.155



The Holcim (US) Inc./Geocycle LLC (Geocycle) facility in Holly Hill, South Carolina manages hazardous waste derived fuels (HWDF) that are used to reduce fossil fuel and natural raw material consumption in the Holcim Portland cement manufacturing facility.  Geocycle has prepared this plan and submitted a predictive RMP Plan to maintain future operational flexibility.   This summary that includes a brief description of the key elements of our Level 2 program:



1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)



Geocycle's prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68, Level 2 Prevention Program.  Key Polices which are implemented include:

1.1.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (A) (1)



Geocycle has a management system that is led by the Facility Manager and supporting staff.  This is depicted in an organization chart.



1.2.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2 (A) (2)

Geocycle maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of our prevention program.  It also includes all requirements for a RCRA hazardous waste facility.



1.3.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT GEOCYCLE, HOLLY HILL, SC SITE   (B)

The Geocycle Plant employs 20 full-time employees engaged in HWDF plant. 



2.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)

The site is owned by Holcim (US) and is managed and operated by Geocycle.  The site is located at 2175 Gardner Blvd, Holly Hill, SC, Orangeburg County.



3.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (B) (2)

HWDFs include both a flammable mixture and toxic chemicals.

Process 1, Tank Farm/Blend Tank System, covers a flammable mixture and 12 toxic chemicals.  In past submittal the chemicals in the flammable mixture were listed as individual flammable chemicals.  Now all of the flammables are listed as constituents of the mixture.

Process 2, Direct Burn System, includes nine toxic as well as each Process number 1, flammable mixture and 12 toxic chemicals 



3.1.

WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS (C)

Offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two release scenarios for each covered HWDF Process.  All results are maintained on site and included in the RMP Submit program.  

3.1.1.    Worst Case (c) (1)

Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed for each flammable and toxic chemical using the EPA's RMP-COMP program.  

3.1.2.    Alternative Case (c) (2)

The alternative release scenario involves a 100-gallon-per-minute leak in a tank, pump, pipe or associated storage and transfer equipment.  Modeling was performed using the EPA's RMP COMP program based on duration of 60 minutes, which is a conservative assumption.



4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE LEVEL 2 PREVENTION PROGRAM (C)

The Geocycle accidental release prevention program is based on EPA's RMP Level 2 prevention program.  Also, Geocycle HWDF policies and procedures meets RCRA requirements for a permitted hazardous waste treatment, storage and disposal facility and MSHA safety standards therefore the plant is exempt from OSHA standards.  



4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (C) (1)

Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written program's elements is listed below:

4.1.1.    Process safety information for chemicals and equipment.  Note all chemicals are waste streams and thus a list of chemicals within a waste stream is certified by the waste supplier.  Geocycle also uses the SDSs for the pure constituents as a guide to the hazards presented.

4.1.2.    A hazards review policy and reports.

4.1.3.    Operating procedures are developed and implemented. 

4.1.4.    Training program is established in each area for subject employees and contractors.  

4.1.5.    Maintenance and preventive maintenance is conducted and documented.

4.1.6.    Geocycle's compliance audits policy is followed. Reports are generated and kept on site.

4.1.7.    Incident investigations of

accidents and near-misses are documented and kept on site. 



4.2.    HWDF-SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (C) (2)

4.2.1.    Chemical-specific prevention for the plant includes the policies and procedures listed above and those of the HWDF specific program.  

4.2.2.    Facility and equipment design meet recognized codes and good engineering standards, such as NFPA.  Recently the plant conducted an Explosion Prevention Survey and the results were documented and implemented.  The Audit used NFPA standards as well as good engineering standards.  The report recommendations were implemented and the report is maintained on site.



5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)

On November 2, 2015 - 7:30 PM; the Material Handler was splashed with a non-RCRA/ non-RMP liquid fuel and sustained an injury.  He was in the process of unhooking the hose from the tanker truck which should not have had any pressure on it.  He opened and closed an inlet valve to the pump thinking he had relieved all the pressure in the unloading hose. In doing so, he closed the valve leading into the pump rather than closing the valve on top of the pump.  When he unhooked the hose from the tanker truck it blew off pressure spraying no more than 20 gallons of the non-RCRA/non-RMP liquid fuel on his body and face, the tanker truck, and the surrounding building walls and floor.  All was contained in the unloading area containment system.  He immediately went to the local eyewash and safety shower and flushed his eyes and skin.  We had him visit a Doctor to evaluate the exposure which resulted in the Material Handler receiving a prescription for eye drops to heal the irritation in his eyes.  The Material Handler was released back to full duty after one day of restricted duty; no lost time from work resulted from this incident.  Based on the incident investigation team report, full face respirators are to be used for unhooking and hooking up hoses to tanker trucks and rail cars.  All affected employees were briefed and other c

orporate wide recommendations are being researched and reviewed for applicability.



6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)

Emergency response procedures are contained in both the Plant Emergency Response Policy and Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan, developed under RCRA requirements for a hazardous waste treatment storage and disposal facility).  Geocycle is a non-responding facility our operators are trained to the HAZMAT Operations level and the Emergency Response Program meets RMP 68.95 described in Section 7 of this plan.



7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)

Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal and subsequent safety Hazards Analysis, tour, and audits in preparation to implement the RMP program.  These were addressed including addition of fire suppression system and back up emergency generator.  Geocycle continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.



8.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2, SUBPART C

The Geocycle prevention program covers both Processes.  

The Geocycle Hazardous Waste Derived Fuels (HWDF) systems and feed to the Holcim cement kiln, related utility and safety systems are subject to the requirements of EPA's Risk Management Program's Level 2 Prevention Program.  

Geocycle has developed and implemented seven elements required by Prevention Program Level 2:

8.1.    Safety Information            68.48

8.2.    Hazard Review            68.50

8.3.    Operating Procedures            68.52

8.4.    Training                68.54

8.5.    Compliance Audits            68.58

8.6.    Incident Investigation            68.60

8.7.    Maintenance                68.56



9.    SAFETY INFORMATION    68.48

Geocycle compiled the safety information required under the RMP regulations.  The safety information assists in the understanding of the safety-related aspects of the equipment and processes, and the limitations placed on the operations and the adopted codes and standards.  First, Geocycle receives hazardous waste, and uses a detailed chemical

analysis and physical property analysis to define each waste stream.  There are no MSDS or SDSs for hazardous waste.  However, a SDS of the individual components is used as a guide.  Next, the bulk containers used for delivering the waste fuel containing the RMP compounds are DOT-specification containers and are required to be tested periodically for tightness and adequacy for carrying hazardous materials.  Documentation of the safety and design information on the typical process equipment, along with the corresponding design codes, is maintained in the plant's current RCRA Permit Application in Section4 - Storage and Process Information (4.3 Hazardous Waste Management), Operations SOPs for Operating Limits and Temporary Operations, Engineering and Maintenance Records.  The 2011/2012 EPD audit report and equipment evaluation confirmed all of the equipment installations were within code.  The information contained on the Safety Information Sheet is reviewed and updated on a periodic basis for completeness and accuracy.  The maximum intended inventory for each RMP Toxic Chemical is listed in the List of Chemicals in Table #1 and #2.  



10.    HAZARD REVIEW    68.50

The facility completed numerous hazard reviews (HR) of its RMP regulated process Hazardous Waste Derived Fuels (HWDF) facility operations.  Reviews were conducted for the following years 

?    Initial HR in December 1999.

?    2001 Update of the 1999 HR.

?    In September of 2006 a HR of the new Direct Burn and existing process.  Then in September 2009, a HR and compliance audit of the blend tanks and derived fuel system was conducted.

?    In 2011 through 2012 a complete explosibility and electrical systems review was completed.  

?    A Hazard Review was conducted on December 2012 of the RMP regulated process.    The more complete Hazards and Operability (HazOp) technique was used for the 2012 review.

?    A Hazard Review was conducted on October 31, 2014 of the improvements to the Vapor Recovery System and a Hazard Rev

iew was conducted on March 24, 2015 of the expansion of the Sprinkler System in the Receiving areas.

Each HR used a multidisciplinary team to conduct the evaluation that identified:

10.1.    Hazards associated with the process and regulated chemicals

10.2.    Potential for equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause a release

10.3.    Safeguards that control the hazards or prevent the malfunction or error

10.4.    Steps to detect or monitor releases

The HR results have been documented and are retained on file at the facility.  Implementation of the HR recommendations is ongoing and essentially a continuing process.  The Hazard Review shall be updated minimally every 5 years or with any process or equipment change that occurs that impacts the covered processes. 



11.    OPERATING PROCEDURES    68.52

Geocycle has written operating procedures (OPs) that describe in detail what tasks a process operator must perform.  The OPs set safe process operating parameters that must be maintained.  It lists the set safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.  These procedures are the guide for employees on how to work safely, providing a readily accessible source of comprehensive information that can prevent or mitigate the effects of an accident.  Finally, it provides workers and management with a standard against which to assess performance.

Geocycle must have written operating procedures for each of the following:

11.1.    Initial start-up

11.2.    Normal operations

11.3.    Temporary operations

11.4.    Emergency shutdown

11.5.    Emergency operations

11.6.    Normal shutdown

11.7.    Startup following a normal or emergency shutdown or a major change

11.8.    Consequence of deviation and steps required to avoid or correct deviations and

11.9.    Equipment inspection

The operating procedures are updated any time there is a change in the process in a way that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Examples of changes that may require an update to the operating procedur

es include:  the installation of new operating equipment, a change in the safety information for the regulated chemical or process equipment, as well as the identification of additional hazards during the updates to the facility hazard review.



12.    TRAINING    68.54

Under the RMP regulation in 40 CFR Part 68.54, all new workers and experienced workers are trained in the Operating Procedures prior to starting working on an RMP covered process.  Also, training is given any time the procedures are revised as everyone must be trained in using the new procedures.  Training for the RMP program is given at least once every three years.  Finally, training will be given more often if necessary; employees will be consulted by Geocycle to establish a refresher training regimen.  Refresher training is provided on the operating procedures even if they have not changed.  The training must cover all parts of the operating procedures, including information on the consequences of deviations and steps needed to address deviations. 

Under the provisions of 40 CFR ? 68.54(c), the facility "may use training conducted under Federal or state regulations or under industry specific standards or codes or training conducted by covered process equipment vendors to demonstrate compliance with this section to the extent that the training meets the requirements of this section".  Under the prevailing federal RCRA regulations, all HWDF facility and cement plant employees associated with hazardous waste operations are trained within 6 months of hire.  The training includes the following:

12.1.    24 Hours initial RCRA/MSHA hazardous waste operations and emergency training  

12.2.    8 hours RCRA/MSHA annual refresher training

12.3.    Classroom and on-the-job training is conducted, along with written examinations as required.  All training logs and records are maintained on site.

7.5.    MAINTENANCE    68.56

Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment are critical to safe operations.  Geocy

cle has developed and implemented procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of process equipment. We also train applicable workers and contractors in the maintenance procedures, under 40 CFR 68.52, 54 and 56. 

As required under 40 CFR 264/265, the facility has implemented Procedures to Prevent Hazards as an integral part of its hazardous waste management operations.  These written procedures meet or exceed the requirements for preventive maintenance, inspection and testing under the RMP regulations and are incorporated by reference.  They provide a detailed list of the equipment to be tested and the inspection frequency.  The schedules already in practice are based on: 

12.4.    Regulatory Compliance Requirements

12.5.    Manufacturer's Recommendations

12.6.    Industry Standards or Codes

12.7.    Good Engineering Practices

All employees associated with preventive maintenance, inspection and testing are trained in these procedures.



13.    COMPLIANCE AUDITS     68.58

Geocycle will review and audit the RMP Plan every three years, at a minimum, to ensure that the plan is implemented and documented adequately.  The audit program is designed to evaluate and measure the effectiveness of the Risk Management Program and ensure that the prevention program elements are up-to-date and appropriate for current operations.

The most recent audit was conducted March 23, 2015 for the entire RMP processes.

The compliance audit will be conducted by an individuals or team; knowledgeable of both the regulated processes as well as the RMP regulations [40 CFR Part 68].  The compliance audit will include a review of all elements of the RMP plan level 2 program located in the EPA Audit Checklist, including:

13.1.    Safety Information

13.2.    Hazard Review

13.3.    Change in Regulated Process or Regulated Chemicals

13.4.    Records

13.5.    The RMP*eSubmittal

Upon completion of the compliance audit, all findings shall be summarized in a written report.  Geocycle will promptly determine and docu

ment an appropriate response to each audit finding and further document all corrective actions taken to address any deficiencies.  Copies of the two most recent compliance audits and documentation of all corrective actions will be maintained at the facility.  A copy of the blank audit form used by South Carolina DHEC is included in Appendix 7.



14.    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION    68.60

Geocycle will perform an investigation of each incident which has resulted in, or could have resulted in a release or catastrophic release of a regulated chemical.  A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  An RMP reportable release is one that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

The following steps will be taken in performing an incident investigation:

14.1.    Initiate an investigation as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident.

14.2.    Summarize the investigation in a report.  Incorporate all factors contributing to the incident including:  date of incident; date investigation began, a description of the incident; the factors that contributed to the incident; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation.

14.3.    Address the investigation findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions shall be documented.

14.4.    The findings shall be reviewed with all affected personnel to prevent future occurrence of similar incidents.

14.5.    Each investigation report is maintained for a minimum of five years.



15.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY    68.155 (F)

Geocycle will Geocycle has an ongoing system to make improvements to our safety program.  Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal and subsequent safety Hazards Analysis, tours, and audits of the RMP program.  Recent change

s included  

15.1.    Update the RMP*eSubmit to include Flammable mixtures instead of listing each flammable constituent separately.  Our 

15.2.    Improved the Fire Suppression System in the Tank truck and rail tanker unloading areas.

15.3.    Installation of a back-up Emergency Generator.

15.4.    Improved splash protection PPE implemented.

We constantly improve safety based on our employee's recommendations, site audits, process hazards analysis and keeping current with the changes to the RMP and related regulations.  We also follow MSHA regulations which include compliance with their regulations.
